questions.explanation: BitTorrent distributes files without a central server.

questions.questionText: Which tool can monitor SNMP-enabled devices and generate alerts?
questions.explanation: PRTG monitors SNMP devices and sends notifications on thresholds.

questions.questionText: Which protocol transfers files over an unencrypted channel?
questions.explanation: FTP transfers files without encryption.

questions.questionText: Which application layer protocol allows web page requests and responses?
questions.explanation: HTTP enables clients to request web pages from servers.

questions.questionText: Which protocol is used to resolve reverse DNS lookups (IP to domain)?
questions.explanation: PTR records in DNS map IP addresses back to domain names.

questions.questionText: Which port is used by default for HTTP traffic?
questions.explanation: HTTP uses port 80 for unencrypted web communication.

questions.questionText: Which protocol allows uploading files to a server?
questions.explanation: FTP supports file uploads via PUT or POST commands.

questions.questionText: Which email protocol allows multiple devices to access the same mailbox simultaneously?
questions.explanation: IMAP supports multiple device access while keeping messages on the server.

questions.questionText: Which tool provides packet sniffing and protocol analysis?
questions.explanation: Wireshark captures and analyzes network packets in real-time.

questions.questionText: Which P2P application can distribute a single file to thousands of users efficiently?
questions.explanation: BitTorrent uses decentralized distribution for efficiency.

questions.questionText: Which protocol provides secure remote login?
questions.explanation: SSH encrypts remote login sessions, unlike Telnet.

questions.questionText: Which port is used by secure FTP (SFTP)?
questions.explanation: SFTP runs over SSH and uses port 22.

questions.questionText: Which tool is primarily used for visualizing network traffic trends over time?
questions.explanation: MRTG graphs SNMP network statistics over time.

questions.questionText: Which protocol is used for sending notifications from network devices to monitoring software?
questions.explanation: SNMP sends alerts (traps) to monitoring systems.

questions.questionText: Which socket type is used for connectionless communication?
questions.explanation: Datagram sockets (UDP) provide connectionless communication.

questions.questionText: Which socket type is used for reliable, connection-oriented communication?
questions.explanation: Stream sockets (TCP) provide reliable, connection-oriented communication.

questions.questionText: Which tool simulates networks and allows testing of routing protocols?
questions.explanation: Packet Tracer simulates network devices and routing protocols.

questions.questionText: Which P2P protocol is considered decentralized and efficient?
questions.explanation: BitTorrent distributes files across peers without a central server.

questions.questionText: Which protocol is used to query DNS for IP addresses?
questions.explanation: DNS queries translate domain names into IP addresses.

questions.questionText: Which email protocol can keep emails on the server while allowing access from multiple devices?
questions.explanation: IMAP keeps emails on the server and supports multiple client access.

questions.questionText: Which traffic analyzer tool captures real-time network packets?
questions.explanation: Wireshark captures and analyzes live network traffic.

questions.questionText: Which port is the default for secure web traffic?
questions.explanation: HTTPS uses port 443 for encrypted web communication.

questions.questionText: Which application allows secure file transfer using graphical interface?
questions.explanation: WinSCP allows secure file transfer over SSH with GUI.

questions.questionText: Which protocol is used for sending bulk emails from servers?
questions.explanation: SMTP is used for sending emails from clients or between servers.

questions.questionText: Which tool can monitor SNMP-enabled devices and alert for thresholds?
questions.explanation: PRTG monitors SNMP devices and sends alerts when thresholds are exceeded.

questions.questionText: Which protocol supports secure remote login and command execution?
questions.explanation: SSH encrypts login and commands for secure remote access.

questions.questionText: Which tool is used to simulate networking for educational purposes?
questions.explanation: Packet Tracer allows students to simulate network devices and configurations.

questions.questionText: Which protocol is used to transfer email from client to server?
questions.explanation: SMTP is used to send emails from clients to mail servers.

questions.questionText: Which P2P protocol allows sharing large files efficiently?
questions.explanation: BitTorrent splits files into pieces for efficient P2P sharing.

questions.questionText: Which application layer protocol allows clients to request web pages?
questions.explanation: HTTP enables clients to request web pages from web servers.

questions.questionText: Which port is used by FTP for control connection?
questions.explanation: FTP uses port 21 for sending commands from client to server.

questions.questionText: Which email protocol downloads and deletes messages from the server?
questions.explanation: POP3 downloads emails and can delete them from the server.

questions.questionText: Which of the following is a type of computer security?
questions.explanation: Computer security includes physical, network, and application security.

questions.questionText: Which type of attack intercepts communication between two parties?
questions.explanation: A man-in-the-middle attack intercepts or alters communication.

questions.questionText: Which principle ensures that only authorized users can access resources?
questions.explanation: Confidentiality restricts access to authorized users.

questions.questionText: Which cryptography type uses the same key for encryption and decryption?
questions.explanation: Symmetric key cryptography uses a shared secret key for both encryption and decryption.

questions.questionText: Which cryptography type uses public and private keys?
questions.explanation: Asymmetric cryptography uses a public key for encryption and private key for decryption.

questions.questionText: RSA algorithm is based on which mathematical problem?
questions.explanation: RSA relies on the difficulty of factoring large integers.

questions.questionText: Digital signatures provide which of the following?
questions.explanation: Digital signatures ensure authentication, integrity, and non-repudiation.

questions.questionText: Which protocol is used to secure emails using encryption and signatures?
questions.explanation: PGP (Pretty Good Privacy) secures email using encryption and digital signatures.

questions.questionText: Which protocol secures TCP connections on the internet?
questions.explanation: SSL/TLS encrypts TCP connections for secure web communication.

questions.questionText: IPsec provides security at which layer?
questions.explanation: IPsec operates at the network layer to secure IP traffic.

questions.questionText: VPN uses which of the following to secure communication over public networks?
questions.explanation: VPN often uses IPsec to encrypt communication over untrusted networks.

questions.questionText: Which encryption protocol was used for early wireless LAN security?
questions.explanation: WEP (Wired Equivalent Privacy) was the original WLAN security protocol.

questions.questionText: Which firewall type inspects the packet headers only?
questions.explanation: Packet-filtering firewalls inspect header information to allow or block packets.

questions.questionText: Which firewall type maintains the state of active connections?
questions.explanation: Stateful firewalls track active connections and make decisions based on state.

questions.questionText: Which of the following is a type of security attack?
questions.explanation: Security attacks are categorized as passive or active attacks.

questions.questionText: Which type of passive attack involves eavesdropping?
questions.explanation: Traffic analysis involves eavesdropping on communication without altering it.

questions.questionText: Which type of active attack involves modifying messages?
questions.explanation: Modification of messages is an active attack where the attacker changes the message content.

questions.questionText: Which principle ensures that data is not altered during transmission?
questions.explanation: Integrity ensures that data remains unaltered and trustworthy.

questions.questionText: SSL/TLS primarily provides which security service?
questions.explanation: SSL/TLS provides encryption, authentication, and integrity for TCP connections.

questions.questionText: Which principle ensures that legitimate users can access resources when needed?
questions.explanation: Availability ensures authorized users can access resources when required.

questions.questionText: Which asymmetric key algorithm is widely used for digital signatures and encryption?
questions.explanation: RSA is a popular asymmetric algorithm used for encryption and digital signatures.

questions.questionText: Which cryptography principle ensures that a sender cannot deny sending a message?
questions.explanation: Non-repudiation prevents the sender from denying sending a message.

questions.questionText: PGP combines which cryptography techniques?
questions.explanation: PGP uses symmetric encryption for speed and asymmetric encryption to exchange keys securely.

questions.questionText: Which IPsec mode encrypts only the payload of IP packets?
questions.explanation: Transport mode encrypts the payload but leaves the header intact.

questions.questionText: Which IPsec mode encrypts the entire IP packet?
questions.explanation: Tunnel mode encrypts the entire IP packet for VPN communication.

questions.questionText: Which WEP vulnerability makes it insecure?
questions.explanation: WEP has weak keys, IV reuse, and is vulnerable to replay attacks.

questions.questionText: Which firewall filters traffic based on application-level information?
questions.explanation: Application firewalls inspect traffic at the application layer.

questions.questionText: Which type of attack attempts to overwhelm network resources?
questions.explanation: DoS attacks aim to exhaust network or server resources.

questions.questionText: Which cryptography service ensures the integrity of messages?
questions.explanation: Hash functions verify that data has not been altered during transmission.

questions.questionText: Which type of attack captures and replays messages?
questions.explanation: Replay attacks resend captured messages to trick the recipient or system.

questions.questionText: Which cryptographic protocol secures web-based email?
questions.explanation: SSL/TLS secures web email (HTTPS-based email access).

questions.questionText: Which type of attack impersonates another user?
questions.explanation: Masquerade attacks use another user's identity to gain access.

questions.questionText: Which cryptography service ensures the sender is authentic?
questions.explanation: Authentication verifies the identity of the sender.

questions.questionText: Which digital signature algorithm is widely used with RSA?
questions.explanation: DSA (Digital Signature Algorithm) is commonly used with RSA for signing.

questions.questionText: Which firewall type acts as an intermediary between client and server?
questions.explanation: Proxy firewalls intercept and forward client requests to servers.

questions.questionText: Which VPN type secures communication over the internet for remote users?
questions.explanation: Remote-access VPN allows individual users to connect securely over the internet.

questions.questionText: Which attack tries to guess passwords by trying many combinations?
questions.explanation: Brute force attacks systematically try all possible passwords.

questions.questionText: Which attack deceives users to reveal confidential information?
questions.explanation: Phishing tricks users into revealing sensitive information like passwords.

questions.questionText: Which protocol provides encrypted communication for web browsing?
questions.explanation: HTTPS encrypts HTTP traffic using SSL/TLS.

questions.questionText: Which network layer security protocol is used to encrypt IP packets?
questions.explanation: IPsec encrypts and authenticates IP packets at the network layer.

questions.questionText: Which wireless security protocol is an improvement over WEP?
questions.explanation: WPA improves security over the insecure WEP protocol.

questions.questionText: Which firewall inspects both packet headers and connection states?
questions.explanation: Stateful firewalls monitor connection states and make dynamic decisions.

questions.questionText: Which principle ensures that transmitted messages cannot be altered without detection?
questions.explanation: Integrity ensures that messages remain unaltered during transmission.

questions.questionText: Which type of attack floods a network with unnecessary traffic?
questions.explanation: Denial of Service attacks overwhelm the network or server to deny service to users.

questions.questionText: Which key exchange method is used in SSL for secure session establishment?
questions.explanation: Diffie-Hellman is used to securely exchange session keys in SSL.

questions.questionText: Which attack attempts to redirect users to malicious websites?
questions.explanation: DNS spoofing redirects users to a fake website by corrupting DNS resolution.

questions.questionText: Which security principle ensures that users cannot deny sending a message?
questions.explanation: Non-repudiation prevents the sender from denying their actions.

questions.questionText: Which type of attack injects malicious code into a website?
questions.explanation: SQL injection attacks insert malicious SQL commands into web forms.

questions.questionText: Which protocol encrypts TCP connections for secure data transfer?
questions.explanation: SSL/TLS provides encryption and authentication for TCP connections.

questions.questionText: Which attack modifies data in transit to deceive the receiver?
questions.explanation: Modification attacks actively change messages during transmission.

questions.questionText: Which firewall type blocks traffic based on application content?
questions.explanation: Application firewalls inspect and filter application-layer traffic.

questions.questionText: Which cryptography service ensures that the message has not been altered?
questions.explanation: Integrity ensures the received data is the same as sent.

questions.questionText: Which type of attack floods a network to deny service to legitimate users?
questions.explanation: DoS attacks overwhelm network resources to block legitimate access.

questions.questionText: Which asymmetric algorithm is widely used for digital signatures?
questions.explanation: RSA is commonly used for both encryption and digital signatures.

questions.questionText: Which wireless security protocol improved on the weaknesses of WEP?
questions.explanation: WPA enhanced security over WEP with stronger encryption and key management.

questions.questionText: Which VPN type encrypts traffic between two networks over the internet?
questions.explanation: Site-to-site VPN connects two networks securely over a public network.

questions.questionText: Which principle ensures that only authorized users access resources?
questions.explanation: Confidentiality protects data from unauthorized access.

questions.questionText: Which attack tricks users into revealing credentials by masquerading as a trusted entity?
questions.explanation: Phishing uses deceptive messages to steal sensitive information.

questions.questionText: Which firewall inspects both packet headers and the state of active connections?
questions.explanation: Stateful firewalls track active sessions and make filtering decisions.

questions.questionText: Which cryptography protocol ensures encrypted email communication?
questions.explanation: PGP encrypts email content and provides authentication using digital signatures.

questions.questionText: Which type of attack involves capturing and resending valid messages?
questions.explanation: Replay attacks resend captured messages to trick recipients or systems.

questions.questionText: Which protocol encrypts IP packets and authenticates their source?
questions.explanation: IPsec secures IP traffic by providing encryption and authentication at the network layer.

questions.questionText: Which principle ensures messages cannot be altered undetectably during transmission?
questions.explanation: Integrity ensures message content remains unchanged.

questions.questionText: Which asymmetric cryptography algorithm relies on the difficulty of factoring large integers?
questions.explanation: RSA security is based on the difficulty of integer factorization.

questions.questionText: Which tool is used for monitoring SNMP-enabled network devices and generating alerts?
questions.explanation: PRTG monitors SNMP devices and alerts administrators on network performance issues.

questions.questionText: Which type of attack impersonates a legitimate user to gain unauthorized access?
questions.explanation: Masquerade attacks use false identity to gain access to systems or data.

questions.questionText: Which SSL/TLS component ensures that the client communicates with the intended server?
questions.explanation: Digital certificates verify server identity to prevent man-in-the-middle attacks.

questions.questionText: Which protocol is used to securely exchange session keys for SSL communication?
questions.explanation: Diffie-Hellman allows secure session key exchange without prior shared secrets.

questions.questionText: Which firewall type inspects traffic between client and server applications?
questions.explanation: Proxy firewalls act as intermediaries and inspect traffic at the application level.

questions.questionText: Which protocol secures email content using public and private keys?
questions.explanation: PGP encrypts emails and signs them using public/private key pairs.

questions.questionText: Which principle ensures authorized users can access network resources when needed?
questions.explanation: Availability ensures systems and data are accessible to authorized users.

questions.questionText: Which attack redirects users to fake websites by modifying DNS responses?
questions.explanation: DNS spoofing manipulates DNS responses to redirect users to malicious sites.

questions.questionText: Which VPN type allows secure communication for individual users over public networks?
questions.explanation: Remote-access VPN enables secure connectivity for individual users.

questions.questionText: Which type of attack overwhelms server resources to make services unavailable?
questions.explanation: DoS attacks flood servers or networks to deny access to legitimate users.

questions.questionText: Which principle ensures the origin of a message is verifiable?
questions.explanation: Authentication verifies the identity of the message sender.

questions.questionText: Which wireless security protocol replaced WEP to provide stronger encryption?
questions.explanation: WPA replaced WEP with improved encryption and key management mechanisms.

title: 6. Theory of Computation and Computer Graphics

questions.questionText: Which operation is used to combine two regular languages into one language containing strings from both?
questions.explanation: Union combines all strings from both languages into one.

questions.questionText: Which operation forms strings by joining one string from L1 with one from L2?
questions.explanation: Concatenation joins strings from two languages in order.

questions.questionText: Which operation repeats a language zero or more times?
questions.explanation: Kleene star allows repetition of language strings zero or more times.

questions.questionText: Which theorem proves equivalence of regular expressions and finite automata?
questions.explanation: Kleene’s Theorem shows every regular expression has an equivalent FA.

questions.questionText: Which lemma is used to prove a language is not regular?
questions.explanation: Pumping lemma shows that certain languages cannot be regular.

questions.questionText: Which condition must a DFA satisfy for minimization?
questions.explanation: Minimization removes unreachable and equivalent states.

questions.questionText: Which method partitions DFA states into equivalent classes?
questions.explanation: Minimization partitions states into equivalent classes for a smaller DFA.

questions.questionText: Which regular operation is closed under DFA?
questions.explanation: Regular languages accepted by DFA are closed under union, intersection, and complement.

questions.questionText: What does a transition function in DFA define?
options: Next state for a given input
questions.explanation: Transition function specifies the next state based on current state and input.

questions.questionText: Which FA type can have multiple transitions for the same symbol from a state?
questions.explanation: NDFA can have multiple transitions for the same input symbol.

questions.questionText: Which FA type is used for lexical analysis in compilers?
questions.explanation: DFA is used in compilers to recognize regular patterns (tokens).

questions.questionText: Which symbol in regular expressions represents empty string?
questions.explanation: ε represents the empty string in regular expressions.

questions.questionText: Which FA component defines which states accept input strings?
questions.explanation: Final states determine if a string is accepted by the automaton.

questions.questionText: Which method converts a regular expression to an NDFA?
questions.explanation: Thompson's construction builds an NDFA from a regular expression.

questions.questionText: Which FA can have ε-transitions that consume no input symbol?
questions.explanation: NDFA can include ε-transitions that do not consume input.

questions.questionText: Which FA concept ensures that two DFAs accept the same language?
questions.explanation: Two DFAs are equivalent if their states are equivalent in accepting strings.

questions.questionText: Which FA is easier to implement in software for pattern matching?
questions.explanation: DFA is simpler to implement as it is deterministic and requires no backtracking.

questions.questionText: Which property makes NDFA non-deterministic?
questions.explanation: NDFA is non-deterministic due to multiple transitions for the same input symbol.

questions.questionText: Which theorem provides a method to convert FA into regular expression?
questions.explanation: Kleene's Theorem ensures FA can be represented as an equivalent regular expression.

questions.questionText: Which lemma proves that some languages like {a^n b^n | n ≥ 0} are not regular?
questions.explanation: Pumping lemma shows languages requiring memory beyond FA are not regular.

questions.questionText: Which method removes unreachable states from a DFA?
questions.explanation: Minimization removes states that cannot be reached from the initial state.

questions.questionText: Which FA component defines the set of input symbols?
questions.explanation: The alphabet is the set of symbols the automaton can read.

questions.questionText: Which operation combines two regular expressions to form strings from either expression?
questions.explanation: Union allows strings from either of the two regular expressions.

questions.questionText: Which operation forms strings by repeating a regular expression multiple times?
questions.explanation: Kleene star represents zero or more repetitions of a pattern.

questions.questionText: Which FA concept is used to minimize the number of states while preserving language?
questions.explanation: States that are equivalent can be merged to minimize the DFA.

questions.questionText: Which FA type cannot have multiple transitions for the same input from a state?
questions.explanation: DFA is deterministic, allowing only one transition per symbol.

questions.questionText: Which lemma is used to show that the language {a^n b^n | n ≥ 0} is not regular?
questions.explanation: Pumping lemma proves languages requiring memory beyond finite automata are not regular.

questions.questionText: Which construction converts NDFA with ε-transitions into equivalent DFA?
questions.explanation: Subset construction builds DFA states as sets of NDFA states.

questions.questionText: Which FA type is used for pattern matching in text editors?
questions.explanation: DFA is fast and deterministic, suitable for string pattern matching.

questions.questionText: Which FA state has no incoming transitions?
questions.explanation: The initial state is the starting point of the automaton.

questions.questionText: Which FA states determine whether a string is accepted?
questions.explanation: Final states indicate acceptance of strings.

questions.questionText: Which theorem proves that for every regular expression, there exists an equivalent finite automaton?
questions.explanation: Kleene’s Theorem shows equivalence between regular expressions and finite automata.

questions.questionText: Which FA property ensures deterministic computation?
options: Exactly one transition per symbol per state
questions.explanation: DFA is deterministic because each state has exactly one transition for each input symbol.

questions.questionText: Which construction is used to convert a regular expression to NDFA?
questions.explanation: Thompson’s construction builds an NDFA from a regular expression.

questions.questionText: Which FA type is generally easier to implement in hardware?
questions.explanation: DFA is easier to implement because it is deterministic.

questions.questionText: Which FA operation forms strings by taking symbols from both languages in sequence?
questions.explanation: Concatenation forms strings by joining strings from two languages.

questions.questionText: Which FA principle is applied to merge equivalent states during minimization?
questions.explanation: Equivalent states are merged to reduce DFA size without changing the language.

questions.questionText: Which FA component maps current state and input to next state?
questions.explanation: Transition function defines the next state for each input.

questions.questionText: Which property of NDFA makes it non-deterministic?
questions.explanation: NDFA allows multiple possible next states for the same input symbol.

questions.questionText: Which lemma is commonly used to demonstrate non-regularity of languages?
questions.explanation: Pumping lemma is used to prove that certain languages are not regular.

questions.questionText: Which regular expression symbol represents the empty string?
questions.explanation: ε represents the empty string in regular expressions.

questions.questionText: Which method is used to prove two DFAs accept the same language?
questions.explanation: Equivalence checking verifies that two DFAs accept exactly the same strings.

questions.questionText: Which FA is capable of accepting all regular languages?
questions.explanation: Both DFA and NDFA accept exactly the set of regular languages.

questions.questionText: Which FA type is used for simple lexical token recognition?
questions.explanation: DFA is deterministic and efficient for token recognition in lexical analysis.

questions.questionText: Which FA component is optional in terms of accepting no strings?
questions.explanation: A DFA can have no final states to accept the empty language.

questions.questionText: Which operation on regular expressions is represented by '+'?
questions.explanation: '+' represents one or more repetitions of a pattern.

questions.questionText: Which theorem ensures that for any DFA, a regular expression exists?
questions.explanation: Kleene’s Theorem states the equivalence of DFAs and regular expressions.

questions.questionText: Which property must DFA satisfy to accept exactly the same language as NDFA?
questions.explanation: Subset construction converts NDFA to equivalent DFA accepting the same language.

questions.questionText: What does CFG stand for in formal languages?
questions.explanation: CFG stands for Context-Free Grammar, used to define context-free languages.

questions.questionText: Which component of CFG represents a set of symbols that can be replaced?
questions.explanation: Non-terminal symbols can be replaced according to production rules in CFG.

questions.questionText: Which CFG component represents actual symbols of the language?
questions.explanation: Terminal symbols are the actual symbols that appear in strings of the language.

questions.questionText: What is the start symbol in a CFG?
questions.explanation: The start symbol is the initial non-terminal from which derivations begin.

questions.questionText: Which rule describes how a non-terminal can be replaced in CFG?
questions.explanation: Production rules define how non-terminals are replaced by strings of terminals and/or non-terminals.

questions.questionText: What is a derivation tree in CFG?
options: A parse tree showing derivation of string
questions.explanation: A derivation tree visually represents how a string is derived using CFG production rules.

questions.questionText: Which derivation replaces the leftmost non-terminal first?
questions.explanation: Leftmost derivation always replaces the leftmost non-terminal first.

questions.questionText: Which derivation replaces the rightmost non-terminal first?
questions.explanation: Rightmost derivation always replaces the rightmost non-terminal first.

questions.questionText: A parse tree is constructed for which purpose?
questions.explanation: Parse trees visually represent the syntactic structure of a string.

questions.questionText: Which grammar is called ambiguous?
options: A grammar with multiple parse trees for the same string
A grammar with no start symbol
questions.explanation: An ambiguous grammar can generate more than one parse tree for the same string.

questions.questionText: Chomsky Normal Form (CNF) restricts productions to which type?
questions.explanation: In CNF, each production is either a pair of non-terminals or a single terminal.

questions.questionText: Greibach Normal Form (GNF) restricts productions to which type?
questions.explanation: In GNF, each production starts with a terminal followed by zero or more non-terminals.

questions.questionText: Backus-Naur Form (BNF) is used to?
questions.explanation: BNF is a notation to formally define the syntax of programming languages.

questions.questionText: What is a pushdown automaton (PDA)?
questions.explanation: PDA is a finite automaton equipped with a stack for memory to recognize context-free languages.

questions.questionText: Which languages are accepted by PDA?
questions.explanation: Pushdown automata recognize exactly the class of context-free languages.

questions.questionText: Equivalence of CFL and PDA means?
options: Every CFL can be recognized by a PDA and vice versa
Every CFL has a finite alphabet
questions.explanation: Context-free languages and pushdown automata are equivalent in expressive power.

questions.questionText: Pumping lemma for CFL is used to?
options: Prove a language is not context-free
questions.explanation: Pumping lemma for CFL proves certain languages cannot be generated by any CFG.

questions.questionText: Which property does every context-free language satisfy?
questions.explanation: CFLs are closed under union but not generally under intersection or complement.

questions.questionText: Bottom-up derivation in CFG is also called?
questions.explanation: Bottom-up derivation constructs the parse tree from leaves to root (shift-reduce).

questions.questionText: Top-down derivation starts from?
options: Start symbol and expands to terminals
questions.explanation: Top-down derivation starts from the start symbol and expands to derive the string.

questions.questionText: Leftmost derivation corresponds to which parsing method?
questions.explanation: Top-down parsing typically uses leftmost derivation.

questions.questionText: Rightmost derivation corresponds to which parsing method?
questions.explanation: Bottom-up parsing corresponds to rightmost derivation in reverse.

questions.questionText: Ambiguity in grammar leads to?
options: Multiple parse trees for same string
questions.explanation: Ambiguous grammar allows multiple parse trees for the same string.

questions.questionText: Which form is suitable for CYK parsing?
questions.explanation: CYK parsing algorithm requires grammar in CNF.

questions.questionText: Which CFL property is not generally closed?
questions.explanation: CFLs are not closed under intersection or complement in general.

questions.questionText: Which CFG representation is widely used in compiler design?
questions.explanation: BNF is widely used to define programming language syntax.

questions.questionText: Which automaton type can be non-deterministic for context-free languages?
questions.explanation: Pushdown automata can be non-deterministic to accept CFLs.

questions.questionText: Which grammar form ensures that each production starts with a terminal?
questions.explanation: GNF requires each production to start with a terminal symbol.

questions.questionText: Which property of CFL allows derivation trees to be split for pumping lemma?
questions.explanation: Pumping lemma uses the structure of parse trees to show repetition.

questions.questionText: Equivalence of CFG and PDA ensures that?
options: Any CFG can be converted to PDA
Any PDA can be converted to CFG
questions.explanation: Every CFL can be recognized by a PDA and every PDA can be converted to CFG.

questions.questionText: Which CFL operation is always closed?
questions.explanation: CFLs are closed under union but not under intersection or complement.

questions.questionText: Which parsing technique uses a stack to handle nested structures?
questions.explanation: PDA uses a stack to manage nested structures in context-free languages.

questions.questionText: Which property helps to detect non-context-free languages?
questions.explanation: Pumping lemma for CFLs proves that certain languages cannot be context-free.

questions.questionText: Which CFL property makes it suitable for representing nested language structures?
questions.explanation: Use of stack in PDA allows recognition of nested structures like balanced parentheses.

questions.questionText: Which type of derivation constructs parse tree from leaves to root?
questions.explanation: Bottom-up derivation (shift-reduce) starts from leaves and builds up to the root.

questions.questionText: Which normal form is suitable for constructing LL parsers?
questions.explanation: GNF is suitable for top-down parsing techniques like LL parsers.

questions.questionText: Which CFG component can appear on the left-hand side of a production?
questions.explanation: Only non-terminals can appear on the left-hand side of a CFG production.

questions.questionText: Which derivation tree approach starts with the start symbol and applies productions top-down?
questions.explanation: Top-down derivation expands from the start symbol down to the terminals.

questions.questionText: Which derivation tree approach starts from leaves and constructs the tree upwards?
questions.explanation: Bottom-up derivation builds the parse tree from terminals up to the start symbol.

questions.questionText: A language generated by a CFG is called?
questions.explanation: Languages generated by CFGs are context-free languages (CFLs).

questions.questionText: Which derivation always replaces the leftmost non-terminal first?
questions.explanation: Leftmost derivation systematically replaces the leftmost non-terminal first.

questions.questionText: Which derivation always replaces the rightmost non-terminal first?
questions.explanation: Rightmost derivation systematically replaces the rightmost non-terminal first.

questions.questionText: A grammar is ambiguous if?
options: It generates multiple parse trees for the same string
questions.explanation: Ambiguity arises when a grammar generates more than one parse tree for the same string.

questions.questionText: Which form restricts productions to the type A → BC or A → a?
questions.explanation: CNF restricts each production to either two non-terminals or a single terminal.

questions.questionText: Which normal form restricts productions to start with a terminal followed by zero or more non-terminals?
questions.explanation: GNF ensures each production begins with a terminal symbol.

questions.questionText: Backus-Naur Form (BNF) is primarily used for?
questions.explanation: BNF is widely used to formally define programming language syntax.

questions.questionText: Pushdown Automata are essentially?
questions.explanation: PDAs are finite automata with a stack to handle nested structures.

questions.questionText: Which type of PDA can accept exactly all context-free languages?

questions.questionText: In 2D graphics, which operation changes the orientation of an object around a fixed point?
questions.explanation: Rotation moves points of an object around a fixed pivot point while maintaining the distance from the pivot.

questions.questionText: Which transformation is used to enlarge or shrink an object in 2D space?
questions.explanation: Scaling increases or decreases the size of an object along the x and/or y axes.

questions.questionText: Reflection in computer graphics can be performed about?
questions.explanation: Reflection can be done about X-axis, Y-axis, or any arbitrary line.

questions.questionText: Shear transformation in 2D graphics results in?
options: Stretching or slanting of an object
questions.explanation: Shearing slants the shape of an object in a particular direction while keeping the area preserved.

questions.questionText: 2D composite transformation refers to?
questions.explanation: Composite transformations combine multiple transformations like translation, rotation, and scaling.

questions.questionText: Which of the following represents the order of transformations for object movement in 2D graphics?
options: It depends on the desired result
questions.explanation: The order of transformations affects the final result, so it depends on the specific requirement.

questions.questionText: In 2D viewing, world coordinates are transformed to screen coordinates using?
questions.explanation: World to screen transformation maps world coordinates to the screen for display.

questions.questionText: The 2D viewing pipeline consists of?
questions.explanation: The viewing pipeline transforms world coordinates into screen coordinates, including modeling, viewing, projection, and clipping.

questions.questionText: Cohen-Sutherland algorithm is used for?
questions.explanation: Cohen-Sutherland algorithm efficiently clips lines against a rectangular viewport.

questions.questionText: In Cohen-Sutherland algorithm, the outcode for a point indicates?
questions.explanation: Outcodes specify the location of a point with respect to the clipping boundaries.

questions.questionText: Liang-Barsky line clipping algorithm is based on?
questions.explanation: Liang-Barsky uses the parametric form of a line to calculate intersections with the clipping window efficiently.

questions.questionText: Which is more efficient for line clipping?
questions.explanation: Liang-Barsky algorithm performs fewer intersection calculations, making it faster than Cohen-Sutherland.

questions.questionText: In 2D transformations, the origin is the fixed point for?
questions.explanation: Rotation about the origin uses (0,0) as the pivot point for angle-based rotation.

questions.questionText: A scaling factor less than 1 causes?
questions.explanation: Scaling with a factor less than 1 reduces the size of the object.

questions.questionText: A scaling factor greater than 1 causes?
questions.explanation: Scaling with a factor greater than 1 enlarges the object in the given direction.

questions.questionText: Negative scaling factor results in?
questions.explanation: Negative scaling reflects the object about the corresponding axis.

questions.questionText: In 2D graphics, rotation by 90 degrees clockwise around the origin requires?
questions.explanation: The formula for 90° clockwise rotation around origin: x' = y, y' = -x.

questions.questionText: Translation of a point (x, y) by (tx, ty) is given by?
questions.explanation: Translation moves a point by adding the translation values to its coordinates.

questions.questionText: Homogeneous coordinates are used in 2D graphics to?
questions.explanation: Homogeneous coordinates allow all affine transformations to be represented uniformly using matrix multiplication.

questions.questionText: Which matrix is used to perform 2D rotation about the origin?
questions.explanation: The rotation matrix [[cosθ, -sinθ], [sinθ, cosθ]] rotates points around the origin.

questions.questionText: Shearing transformation matrix along x-axis is given by?
questions.explanation: Shearing along x-axis changes x coordinates proportional to y, represented by [[1, shx],[0,1]].

questions.questionText: Which operation preserves parallelism of lines in 2D graphics?
questions.explanation: Translation, scaling, and rotation preserve parallel lines in 2D space.

questions.questionText: Composite transformation can be represented using?
questions.explanation: Multiple transformations can be combined into a single matrix using matrix multiplication.

questions.questionText: Order of matrix multiplication matters in 2D composite transformation?
questions.explanation: Matrix multiplication is not commutative; changing the order changes the final result.

questions.questionText: 2D clipping is required to?
options: Display only visible parts of objects
questions.explanation: Clipping ensures only the portions inside the viewport are displayed.

questions.questionText: In Cohen-Sutherland line clipping, a line is trivially accepted if?
options: Both endpoints are inside the window
Both endpoints are outside the window
questions.explanation: If both endpoints lie inside, the line is fully visible and accepted without further calculation.

questions.questionText: In Cohen-Sutherland line clipping, a line is trivially rejected if?
options: Logical AND of outcodes is non-zero
questions.explanation: If logical AND of outcodes of endpoints is non-zero, the line lies completely outside and is rejected.

questions.questionText: Liang-Barsky algorithm is more efficient than Cohen-Sutherland because?
questions.explanation: It uses parametric line equations and fewer comparisons for clipping.

questions.questionText: Scaling about an arbitrary point requires?
options: Translation to origin → Scaling → Translation back
questions.explanation: Scaling about a point other than origin is done by translating, scaling, then translating back.

questions.questionText: Rotation about an arbitrary point (xr, yr) involves?
options: Translation to origin → Rotation → Translation back
questions.explanation: To rotate about an arbitrary point, the object is first translated so that the point is at origin, rotated, then translated back.

questions.questionText: Which transformation can change the shape of a square into a parallelogram?
questions.explanation: Shearing slants the shape, converting a square into a parallelogram.

questions.questionText: In homogeneous coordinates, a 2D point (x, y) is represented as?
questions.explanation: Homogeneous coordinates represent (x, y) as (x, y, 1) to allow matrix transformations.

questions.questionText: Which of the following is NOT an affine transformation?
questions.explanation: Perspective projection is a non-affine transformation because it does not preserve parallel lines.

questions.questionText: Reflection about the line y = x transforms point (x, y) to?
questions.explanation: Reflection about y = x swaps the coordinates of the point.

questions.questionText: Reflection about the origin transforms point (x, y) to?
questions.explanation: Reflection about origin inverts both x and y coordinates.

questions.questionText: Which operation can convert a rectangle into a square?
questions.explanation: Uniform scaling changes the size equally along both axes, preserving the shape.

questions.questionText: Non-uniform scaling changes?
questions.explanation: Non-uniform scaling scales x and y axes differently, changing size and possibly shape.

questions.questionText: In 2D graphics, an object's local coordinates are transformed to world coordinates using?
questions.explanation: World transformation maps object coordinates from local space to global (world) coordinates.

questions.questionText: Screen coordinates are obtained by?
questions.explanation: World-to-screen transformation maps coordinates from world space to device screen space.

questions.questionText: Viewport transformation converts?
questions.explanation: Viewport transformation maps the normalized coordinates into actual device screen coordinates.

questions.questionText: The main idea of clipping is to?
questions.explanation: Clipping removes portions of graphics outside the defined viewport.

questions.questionText: Which outcode represents a point inside the clipping window in Cohen-Sutherland algorithm?
questions.explanation: Outcode 0000 indicates that the point is inside all boundaries.

questions.questionText: In Liang-Barsky algorithm, t values represent?
questions.explanation: t is the parametric value along the line segment used to find intersection with clipping boundaries.

questions.questionText: The clipping window in 2D is usually?
questions.explanation: Most 2D line clipping algorithms assume a rectangular viewport for simplicity.

questions.questionText: Which transformation can be represented using a 2x3 matrix in homogeneous coordinates?
questions.explanation: Affine transformations like translation, rotation, scaling can all be represented with 2x3 matrices in homogeneous coordinates.

questions.questionText: Translation matrix in homogeneous coordinates is?
questions.explanation: Translation matrix in homogeneous coordinates adds tx and ty to x and y respectively.

questions.questionText: Rotation about the origin in homogeneous coordinates uses matrix?
questions.explanation: Homogeneous rotation matrix applies rotation while keeping translation zero.

questions.questionText: Scaling in homogeneous coordinates uses matrix?
questions.explanation: Scaling matrix in homogeneous coordinates multiplies x and y by sx and sy respectively.

questions.questionText: Shearing in homogeneous coordinates can slant along?
questions.explanation: Shearing can occur along both axes using appropriate matrix values.

questions.questionText: Which transformation keeps angles and lengths unchanged?
questions.explanation: Rotation preserves distances and angles between points.

questions.questionText: Which transformation does NOT preserve parallelism?
questions.explanation: Perspective projection is non-linear and does not preserve parallel lines.

questions.questionText: Line clipping is important in graphics to?
questions.explanation: Clipping improves rendering efficiency and ensures only visible parts are displayed.

questions.questionText: Which coordinate system is used as reference for object positioning in 2D graphics?
questions.explanation: World coordinates define the position of objects in a global reference frame.

questions.questionText: Viewport transformation maps which coordinates to screen coordinates?
questions.explanation: Normalized device coordinates are mapped to screen coordinates via viewport transformation.

questions.questionText: In 2D composite transformations, which is applied first when scaling about a point (xp, yp)?
questions.explanation: The object is first translated to origin before scaling about the point.

questions.questionText: The homogeneous coordinate of a 2D point allows?
questions.explanation: Homogeneous coordinates enable representation of translation as matrix multiplication with other transformations.

questions.questionText: Which algorithm is preferred for line clipping in hardware implementations?
questions.explanation: Liang-Barsky algorithm requires fewer calculations, making it suitable for hardware.

questions.questionText: Which of the following operations is linear in 2D graphics?
questions.explanation: Translation is technically affine (not purely linear), whereas scaling and rotation are linear in homogeneous coordinates.

questions.questionText: 2D transformations are usually represented using which mathematical tool?
questions.explanation: Matrices provide a compact and consistent way to represent and combine 2D transformations.

questions.questionText: Reflection about the x-axis transforms point (x, y) to?
questions.explanation: Reflection about x-axis negates the y-coordinate.

questions.questionText: Reflection about the y-axis transforms point (x, y) to?
questions.explanation: Reflection about y-axis negates the x-coordinate.

questions.questionText: Line clipping ensures?
options: Only visible portions of lines are drawn
questions.explanation: Clipping removes invisible portions outside the viewport for efficiency.

questions.questionText: The final stage of 2D viewing pipeline is?
questions.explanation: After transformations and projection, clipping and mapping to the screen completes the pipeline.

questions.questionText: Cohen-Sutherland algorithm uses which technique to simplify clipping?
questions.explanation: It uses region codes (outcodes) to quickly identify trivially accepted or rejected lines.

questions.questionText: Which transformation changes orientation of an object but not shape or size?
questions.explanation: Rotation preserves shape and size while changing orientation.

questions.questionText: Which transformation is used to produce shadow effects in 2D graphics?
questions.explanation: Shearing can create a skewed projection of an object to simulate shadows.

questions.questionText: World to screen transformation involves which operations?
questions.explanation: World coordinates are translated and scaled to fit the screen viewport.

questions.questionText: What is the purpose of 3D translation in computer graphics?
options: Move an object from one position to another in 3D space
Change the size of an object
questions.explanation: 3D translation shifts an object along x, y, and z axes without altering its orientation or size.

questions.questionText: 3D scaling changes an object's?
options: Size along x, y, and z axes
questions.explanation: Scaling enlarges or shrinks an object along one or more axes.

questions.questionText: Rotation about the x-axis affects which coordinates?
questions.explanation: Rotation about the x-axis changes y and z coordinates, keeping x constant.

questions.questionText: Rotation about the y-axis affects which coordinates?
questions.explanation: Rotation about the y-axis changes x and z coordinates, keeping y constant.

questions.questionText: Rotation about the z-axis affects which coordinates?
questions.explanation: Rotation about the z-axis changes x and y coordinates, keeping z constant.

questions.questionText: Reflection in 3D can be performed about?
options: Any of the three principal planes
questions.explanation: Reflection can be done about XY, YZ, or XZ planes in 3D space.

questions.questionText: Shearing in 3D changes?
questions.explanation: 3D shearing slants the object along one axis relative to another, altering angles and shape.

questions.questionText: Composite 3D transformations combine?
questions.explanation: Composite transformations allow applying multiple 3D transformations in a single sequence.

questions.questionText: Homogeneous coordinates in 3D use how many components?
questions.explanation: 3D points are represented as (x, y, z, 1) in homogeneous coordinates.

questions.questionText: 3D translation matrix in homogeneous coordinates is?
questions.explanation: 3D translation is represented by a 4x4 matrix in homogeneous coordinates.

questions.questionText: Scaling about an arbitrary point in 3D involves?
options: Translation to origin → Scaling → Translation back
questions.explanation: The object is translated to the origin, scaled, and then translated back.

questions.questionText: Rotation about an arbitrary axis in 3D requires?
questions.explanation: To rotate about an arbitrary axis, the axis is aligned with a principal axis, rotation applied, then restored.

questions.questionText: Which transformation preserves distances and angles in 3D?
questions.explanation: Rotation preserves the shape and size of 3D objects.

questions.questionText: Which 3D transformation changes only the position but not shape or orientation?
questions.explanation: Translation moves objects without changing their shape or orientation.

questions.questionText: Perspective projection simulates?
questions.explanation: Perspective projection mimics human vision by making distant objects appear smaller.

questions.questionText: Orthographic projection preserves?
questions.explanation: Orthographic projection maintains parallel lines and true dimensions but ignores perspective foreshortening.

questions.questionText: Parallel projection can be?
questions.explanation: Parallel projections include orthographic and oblique types.

questions.questionText: 3D viewing pipeline stages include?
questions.explanation: The viewing pipeline transforms 3D objects from world to screen coordinates through multiple stages.

questions.questionText: Which 3D transformation can produce a shadow effect?
questions.explanation: Shearing can be used to project a 3D object onto a plane to simulate shadows.

questions.questionText: A rotation matrix about x-axis in 3D is of size?
questions.explanation: 3D rotations in homogeneous coordinates are represented using 4x4 matrices.

questions.questionText: Reflection in 3D about XY plane negates which coordinate?
questions.explanation: Reflection about XY plane flips the z-coordinate.

questions.questionText: Reflection about YZ plane negates which coordinate?
questions.explanation: Reflection about YZ plane flips the x-coordinate.

questions.questionText: Reflection about XZ plane negates which coordinate?
questions.explanation: Reflection about XZ plane flips the y-coordinate.

questions.questionText: Shear along x-axis in 3D changes?
questions.explanation: Shearing along x-axis slants the object in y or z directions.

questions.questionText: 3D composite transformation can be represented using?
questions.explanation: Multiple 3D transformations can be combined into a single 4x4 matrix for efficiency.

questions.questionText: Perspective projection causes parallel lines to appear?
questions.explanation: Perspective projection makes parallel lines converge toward vanishing points.

questions.questionText: Which projection type is used for technical drawings?
questions.explanation: Orthographic projection preserves true dimensions and is preferred for engineering drawings.

questions.questionText: Oblique projection distorts?
questions.explanation: Oblique projection preserves front face dimensions but distorts depth.

questions.questionText: Near and far clipping planes in 3D are used to?
options: Remove invisible objects outside the view volume
questions.explanation: Clipping planes restrict the scene to the portion visible to the camera.

questions.questionText: In perspective projection, the z-coordinate determines?
questions.explanation: Objects farther away (larger z) appear smaller due to perspective scaling.

questions.questionText: In 3D, translation by (tx, ty, tz) moves point (x, y, z) to?
questions.explanation: Translation in 3D adds tx, ty, tz to x, y, z coordinates respectively.

questions.questionText: Uniform scaling in 3D scales the object along?
questions.explanation: Uniform scaling enlarges or shrinks an object equally along x, y, and z axes.

questions.questionText: Non-uniform scaling in 3D scales the object along?
questions.explanation: Non-uniform scaling applies different scaling factors along each axis.

questions.questionText: Rotation about z-axis in 3D keeps which coordinate unchanged?
questions.explanation: Rotation about z-axis changes x and y but keeps z constant.

questions.questionText: 3D shear transformation requires how many parameters for full control?
questions.explanation: Full 3D shearing uses 9 parameters to define slant along each axis relative to the others.

questions.questionText: Reflection about an arbitrary plane in 3D requires?
questions.explanation: Reflection about a plane is computed using vector projection formulas.

questions.questionText: Composite transformation matrix in 3D is always of size?
questions.explanation: 3D homogeneous transformations are represented using 4x4 matrices.

questions.questionText: Order of transformations in 3D matters because?
questions.explanation: Matrix multiplication is not commutative, so the order affects the final result.

questions.questionText: Which 3D transformation preserves parallelism and angles?
questions.explanation: Rotation preserves lengths, angles, and parallelism.

questions.questionText: Perspective projection maps points using?
questions.explanation: Perspective projection divides x and y by z to simulate depth.

questions.questionText: Parallel projection can be used to?
questions.explanation: Parallel projections maintain scale along axes without perspective distortion.

questions.questionText: In oblique projection, front face is?
questions.explanation: Oblique projection preserves the front face true size; depth is skewed.

questions.questionText: Near and far clipping planes define?
questions.explanation: Clipping planes restrict the visible depth range in 3D graphics.

questions.questionText: 3D viewing transformation maps world coordinates to?
questions.explanation: World coordinates are first mapped to camera/view coordinates before projection.

questions.questionText: In perspective projection, objects farther away appear?
questions.explanation: Perspective projection makes distant objects appear smaller.

questions.questionText: Orthographic projection is mainly used for?
questions.explanation: Orthographic projection preserves true dimensions and is ideal for engineering drawings.

questions.questionText: Rotation about an arbitrary axis can be performed using?
questions.explanation: Rodrigues’ rotation formula allows rotation about any arbitrary axis in 3D.

questions.questionText: Translation matrix in homogeneous 3D coordinates is?
questions.explanation: Translation matrix is 4x4 in homogeneous coordinates with [0 0 0 1] in last row.

questions.questionText: Which projection type is best for realistic 3D visualization?
questions.explanation: Perspective projection simulates real-world depth perception.

questions.questionText: Viewport transformation in 3D maps points to?
questions.explanation: Viewport transformation converts normalized coordinates into actual screen coordinates.

questions.questionText: 3D clipping ensures?
options: Only visible parts of objects are rendered
questions.explanation: Clipping removes invisible portions outside the view volume.

questions.questionText: In 3D, rotation about y-axis matrix keeps which coordinate unchanged?
questions.explanation: Rotation about y-axis keeps y coordinate constant while changing x and z.

questions.questionText: Reflection about XZ plane flips?
questions.explanation: XZ plane reflection negates the y-coordinate.

questions.questionText: Reflection about YZ plane flips?
questions.explanation: YZ plane reflection negates the x-coordinate.

questions.questionText: Reflection about XY plane flips?
questions.explanation: XY plane reflection negates the z-coordinate.

questions.questionText: Shearing along z-axis affects which coordinates?
questions.explanation: Shearing along z-axis slants x or y coordinates relative to z.

questions.questionText: Perspective division in 3D graphics is performed using?
questions.explanation: Perspective projection divides x and y by z to achieve depth effect.

questions.questionText: Parallel projection ignores?
questions.explanation: Parallel projections maintain object size along axes, ignoring perspective depth.

questions.questionText: Oblique projection angle affects?
questions.explanation: Oblique projection skews depth based on the chosen projection angle.

questions.questionText: Which transformation does not preserve angles in 3D?
questions.explanation: Shearing changes angles and distorts shape.

questions.questionText: In 3D graphics, homogeneous coordinates allow?
options: Combining translation with rotation and scaling using matrices
questions.explanation: Homogeneous coordinates enable combining all affine transformations in a single 4x4 matrix.

questions.questionText: Near and far plane clipping is essential for?
questions.explanation: It helps in removing objects outside the view volume, improving rendering efficiency.

questions.questionText: In 3D composite transformation, the last applied matrix is?
questions.explanation: The right-most matrix in multiplication is applied first due to matrix multiplication order.

questions.questionText: Depth information in perspective projection is used for?
questions.explanation: Depth values are used in z-buffer to correctly render visible surfaces.

questions.questionText: Projection matrix in 3D graphics maps points to?
questions.explanation: The projection matrix converts camera coordinates into normalized device coordinates.

questions.questionText: Which 3D transformation can change an object's shape?
questions.explanation: Shearing distorts the object by slanting its faces, altering its shape.

questions.questionText: Perspective projection matrix requires which parameter for depth?
questions.explanation: Near and far clipping planes define the depth range for perspective projection.

questions.questionText: Which 3D transformation is linear?
questions.explanation: Rotation is linear; translation is affine, and perspective projection is non-linear.

questions.questionText: 3D viewing pipeline transforms coordinates from world to?
questions.explanation: The 3D viewing pipeline involves world → camera → clip → normalized device coordinates → screen mapping.

questions.questionText: Which transformation in 3D graphics can be combined using matrix multiplication?
questions.explanation: All affine transformations can be represented and combined using 4x4 matrices.

questions.questionText: Which 3D transformation preserves distances but may change orientation?
questions.explanation: Rotation preserves distances and angles but may change the object’s orientation.

questions.questionText: Which type of projection is commonly used for 3D CAD modeling?
questions.explanation: Orthographic projection preserves true dimensions and is widely used in CAD applications.

questions.questionText: Which 3D transformation can be represented using a single 4x4 matrix?
questions.explanation: Multiple transformations (translation, rotation, scaling, shear) can be combined into a single 4x4 matrix.

questions.questionText: Depth cue in perspective projection is achieved by?
options: Scaling x and y by z
questions.explanation: Perspective projection divides x and y coordinates by z to simulate depth perception.

questions.questionText: In 3D graphics, clipping is applied to?
options: Only coordinates outside the view volume
questions.explanation: Clipping removes portions of objects outside the defined view volume for rendering efficiency.

questions.questionText: Which transformation can skew a 3D object along one axis relative to others?
questions.explanation: Shearing slants the object along one axis relative to others, altering its shape.

questions.questionText: Perspective projection lines converge at?
questions.explanation: In perspective projection, parallel lines appear to converge at a vanishing point.

questions.questionText: The z-buffer algorithm uses which information?
questions.explanation: Z-buffer stores depth values to resolve visibility of surfaces.

questions.questionText: Which 3D transformation can produce shadows?
questions.explanation: Shearing can project an object onto a plane to simulate shadows.

questions.questionText: In 3D, rotation about an arbitrary axis requires?
questions.explanation: To rotate about an arbitrary axis, the axis is aligned to a principal axis, rotated, and restored.

questions.questionText: Near and far clipping planes prevent rendering of?
options: Objects too close or too far
questions.explanation: Objects outside the depth range defined by near and far planes are clipped.

questions.questionText: Which 3D transformation is non-linear?
questions.explanation: Perspective projection is non-linear because of the division by the z-coordinate.

questions.questionText: Which 3D transformation preserves angles but not necessarily lengths?
questions.explanation: Rotation preserves angles and lengths; scaling changes lengths; shearing changes angles.

questions.questionText: Which 3D projection is used to simulate human vision?
questions.explanation: Perspective projection simulates human depth perception.

questions.questionText: In 3D composite transformation, matrix multiplication order is?
questions.explanation: The right-most matrix in the multiplication sequence is applied first.

questions.questionText: Homogeneous coordinates allow which operation to be represented as matrix multiplication?
questions.explanation: Homogeneous coordinates allow all affine transformations to be represented as matrix multiplication.

questions.questionText: Orthographic projection preserves?
questions.explanation: Orthographic projection preserves parallel lines and actual dimensions without perspective distortion.

questions.questionText: Oblique projection preserves?
options: Front face dimensions, depth is skewed
questions.explanation: Oblique projection maintains front face true size while skewing depth.

questions.questionText: Which 3D transformation can combine multiple transformations into one?
questions.explanation: Composite transformation combines translation, rotation, scaling, and shear into a single matrix.

questions.questionText: Z-coordinate in perspective projection determines?
options: Object size reduction due to distance
questions.explanation: In perspective projection, objects farther away (larger z) appear smaller.

title: 7. Data Structures and Algorithm, Database System and Operating System

subtitles.subtitle: 7.1 - Introduction to data structure, list, linked lists and trees

questions.questionText: Which of the following is an abstract data type?
questions.explanation: An abstract data type (ADT) defines operations without specifying implementation. Stack is an ADT.

questions.questionText: What is the time complexity of accessing an element in an array?
questions.explanation: Array allows direct indexing, so access is constant time O(1).

questions.questionText: Which of the following represents the worst-case time complexity notation?
questions.explanation: Big O notation represents the upper bound or worst-case complexity.

questions.questionText: Which data structure is LIFO?
questions.explanation: Stack follows Last In First Out (LIFO) principle.

questions.questionText: Which data structure is FIFO?
questions.explanation: Queue follows First In First Out (FIFO) principle.

questions.questionText: The space complexity of a linked list with n elements is?
questions.explanation: Linked list requires storage proportional to the number of elements, i.e., O(n).

questions.questionText: Which is a linear data structure?
questions.explanation: Linear data structures organize elements sequentially. Stack is linear.

questions.questionText: Which operation is used to remove an element from a stack?
questions.explanation: Pop removes the top element from a stack.

questions.questionText: The postfix evaluation uses which data structure?
questions.explanation: Stack is used to evaluate postfix expressions.

questions.questionText: Which of the following is a static data structure?
questions.explanation: Array has fixed size defined at compile time, making it static.

questions.questionText: Dynamic data structures are allocated at?
questions.explanation: Dynamic data structures like linked lists allocate memory at run time.

questions.questionText: Doubly linked list uses?
questions.explanation: Each node has previous and next pointers.

questions.questionText: Deletion in a doubly linked list requires updating?
questions.explanation: Pointers of adjacent nodes must be updated to remove a node.

questions.questionText: Level of a node in a tree is?
questions.explanation: Level is the number of edges from root to that node.

questions.questionText: In a binary tree with n nodes, maximum number of edges is?
questions.explanation: A tree with n nodes has n-1 edges.

questions.questionText: Infix expression A + B * C is converted to postfix as?
questions.explanation: Postfix (Reverse Polish Notation) for A + B * C is A B C * +.

questions.questionText: The height of a binary tree is?
options: Length of longest path from root to leaf
questions.explanation: Height is the length of the longest path from root to any leaf node.

questions.questionText: AVL tree is a type of?
questions.explanation: AVL tree is a self-balancing binary search tree.

questions.questionText: Balance factor of a node in AVL tree is?
options: Height of left subtree − Height of right subtree
Height of right subtree − Height of left subtree
questions.explanation: Balance factor = height(left) − height(right).

questions.questionText: Which operation maintains AVL tree balance after insertion?
questions.explanation: Rotation (single or double) is used to rebalance AVL trees.

questions.questionText: Which linked list allows traversal in both directions?
questions.explanation: Doubly linked list has pointers to both previous and next nodes.

questions.questionText: Circular linked list connects?
questions.explanation: In circular linked list, the last node points back to the first node.

questions.questionText: Insertion at the beginning of a singly linked list requires?
questions.explanation: Head pointer must be updated to the new node.

questions.questionText: Deleting a node in a singly linked list at a given position requires?
questions.explanation: We need to reach the previous node to update its next pointer.

questions.questionText: Pre-order traversal sequence is?
questions.explanation: Pre-order visits root first, then left subtree, then right subtree.

questions.questionText: In-order traversal sequence is?
questions.explanation: In-order visits left subtree, root, then right subtree.

questions.questionText: Post-order traversal sequence is?
questions.explanation: Post-order visits left subtree, right subtree, then root.

questions.questionText: Which tree allows at most two children per node?
questions.explanation: Binary tree nodes have at most two children.

questions.questionText: Which data structure is used for recursion?
questions.explanation: Stack stores return addresses and local variables in recursion.

questions.questionText: Queue can be implemented using?
questions.explanation: Queue can be implemented using both arrays and linked lists.

questions.questionText: Depth of a tree node is?
questions.explanation: Depth measures distance from the root node.

questions.questionText: Degree of a node is?
questions.explanation: Degree is the number of children a node has.

questions.questionText: Leaf node has?
questions.explanation: Leaf node has zero children.

questions.questionText: Parent node has?
questions.explanation: Parent node has at least one child.

questions.questionText: Binary search tree allows search in time complexity?
questions.explanation: Balanced BST allows search in O(log n) time.

questions.questionText: Which traversal is used to delete all nodes in a tree?
questions.explanation: Post-order deletes children before deleting parent nodes.

questions.questionText: Circular queue is preferred to avoid?
questions.explanation: Circular queue allows reusing freed spaces in front of the array.

questions.questionText: Static list is implemented using?
questions.explanation: Static lists use arrays with fixed size.

questions.questionText: Dynamic list is implemented using?
questions.explanation: Dynamic lists use linked lists allowing variable size.

questions.questionText: Stack can be used for?
questions.explanation: Stack is used in infix-postfix conversion and tree traversal algorithms.

questions.questionText: In circular linked list, insertion at the end requires updating?
questions.explanation: Tail.next points to new node, and new node.next points to head.

questions.questionText: Binary tree insertion maintains?
questions.explanation: Standard binary tree insertion preserves the binary search tree property.

questions.questionText: Level-order traversal uses which data structure?
questions.explanation: Queue is used for level-order traversal (BFS) of trees.

questions.questionText: Which of the following sorting algorithms is stable?
questions.explanation: Insertion sort is stable because it preserves the relative order of equal elements.

questions.questionText: Which sorting algorithm repeatedly selects the minimum element?
questions.explanation: Selection sort selects the smallest element and swaps it into the correct position.

questions.questionText: Which sorting algorithm works by repeatedly swapping adjacent elements?
questions.explanation: Exchange sort (Bubble sort) swaps adjacent elements until sorted.

questions.questionText: Merge sort uses which approach?
questions.explanation: Merge sort divides the array into halves, sorts recursively, and merges them.

questions.questionText: Which sorting algorithm is suitable for external sorting?
questions.explanation: Merge sort can handle data that doesn’t fit in memory efficiently.

questions.questionText: BFS uses which data structure?
questions.explanation: Breadth First Search uses queue.

questions.questionText: Topological sorting is applicable to?

questions.questionText: Minimum spanning tree connects all vertices with?
questions.explanation: MST has minimum sum of edge weights without cycles.

questions.questionText: Prim’s algorithm starts from?

questions.questionText: Kruskal’s algorithm works by?
questions.explanation: Kruskal’s algorithm selects edges in increasing weight avoiding cycles.

questions.questionText: Shortest path in weighted graph can be computed by?
questions.explanation: Dijkstra’s algorithm finds shortest path from source to all vertices in weighted graph.

questions.questionText: Shell sort is based on?
questions.explanation: Shell sort uses gap-based insertion sort to improve performance.

questions.questionText: Time complexity of binary search is?
questions.explanation: Binary search halves the search space each step giving O(log n) complexity.

questions.questionText: Sequential search worst-case complexity is?
questions.explanation: We may need to check all elements in worst case.

questions.questionText: Heap sort efficiency in worst case is?
questions.explanation: Heap sort has worst-case complexity of O(n log n).

questions.questionText: Merge sort worst-case time complexity is?
questions.explanation: Merge sort consistently divides and merges giving O(n log n) time.

questions.questionText: Greedy algorithm is used in?

questions.questionText: In adjacency matrix, cell (i,j) = 1 means?

questions.explanation: Matrix cell 1 indicates an edge from vertex i to j.

questions.questionText: Round-robin algorithm is used for?
questions.explanation: Round-robin is used in scheduling and sometimes MST approximations.

questions.questionText: Binary search tree insertion ensures?
questions.explanation: BST property must be maintained for search efficiency.

questions.questionText: Transitive closure of graph is computed by?
questions.explanation: Warshall’s algorithm computes transitive closure.

questions.questionText: Dijkstra’s algorithm does not work with?

questions.questionText: Selection sort best-case time complexity is?

questions.questionText: Insertion sort worst-case occurs when?

questions.questionText: Heap sort is considered?

questions.questionText: Radix sort time complexity is?

questions.questionText: Shell sort worst-case complexity is?

questions.questionText: External sorting is required when?
questions.explanation: External sorting handles data stored on disk that exceeds memory size.

questions.questionText: Hash table provides?
questions.explanation: Hashing allows average O(1) time for search, insert, and delete.

questions.questionText: Collision in hashing occurs when?
options: Two keys map to same index
questions.explanation: Collision occurs when hash function maps multiple keys to same slot.

questions.questionText: Linear probing handles collisions by?
questions.explanation: Linear probing searches the next available index sequentially.

questions.questionText: Chaining handles collisions by?
questions.explanation: Each hash table index contains a linked list of keys.

questions.questionText: DFS traversal can detect?

questions.questionText: BFS is suitable for?

questions.questionText: Topological sort can be obtained using?

questions.questionText: Minimum spanning tree ensures?

questions.questionText: Prim’s algorithm always chooses?

questions.questionText: Kruskal’s algorithm sorts edges by?

questions.questionText: Round-robin algorithm is based on?

questions.questionText: Weighted graph shortest path can be found using?

questions.questionText: Unweighted graph shortest path can be found using?

questions.questionText: Adjacency list representation is suitable when?

questions.questionText: Adjacency matrix uses memory of?

questions.questionText: DFS traversal order is?

questions.questionText: BFS traversal order is?

questions.questionText: Insertion sort best-case occurs when?

questions.questionText: Heap sort stability?
